author: ajsutton
content: So given that a validator may sometimes be selected to produce more than 1 block in a single epoch, and that the randao_reveal is that validator's signature over the epoch number - does that mean the second block they produce would have the exact same randao_reveal and thus be predictable? I can't imagine it would have any material effect on the amount of randomness but seemed interesting...

author: ralexstokes
content: so the `randao_reveal` should either sign over the slot

author: ralexstokes
content: or we say that the chances of this happening are so low, it isn't worth updating the spec

author: .paulharris
content: someone calculated this somewhere with 1348 validators it was something like once in 6 months statistically.. not sure if thats 100% right, but that doesn't sound that low...

author: ajsutton
content: <@!144468805697929216> Did the math over on the Prysm discord: "This gives us an expectation that we will have a validator with more than one proposal slots in an epoch roughly every 6.5 years.  Not high, but not 0 either."  I suspect missing blocks will have much more impact on randomness than proposing twice in an epoch.

author: .paulharris
content: that's it! ok 6 months was way off :/ thanks adrian

author: ajsutton
content: Probably only need to change if we ever introduce penalties for revealing your randao too early.
